tn.text: in-law** - This refers to the father of the wife of Moses.

tn.ref: took Zipporah, Moses' wife ... and her two sons
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Jethro took Zipporah and her two sons to Moses, or 2) Jethro had earlier welcomed back Zipporah and her two sons.

tn.ref: after he had sent her home
tn.text: This is something Moses had done earlier. The full meaning of the can be made explicit. AT: "after Moses had sent her home to her parents" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is a son of Moses and Zipporah, whose name means "foreigner." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is a son of Moses and Zipporah, whose name means "God is the one who helps me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This represents being killed by Pharaoh or Pharaoh's army. AT: "being killed by Pharaoh" or "being killed by Pharaoh's army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "where he camped with the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These symbolic acts were the normal way that people showed great respect and devotion in that culture. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
The word "Israel" represents the Israelite people. AT: "in order to help the Israelite people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: all the hardships that had come to them
tn.text: Moses writes of hardships happening to them as if hardships had come to them. AT: "all the hardships that had happened to them" or "all the hardships they had experienced" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the hand of the Egyptians ... the hand of Pharaoh
tn.text: The hand represents the power of someone to do something. AT: "the power of the Egyptians ... the power of Pharaoh" or "what the Egyptians were doing to you ... what Pharaoh was doing to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: What is this that you are doing with the people?
tn.text: Jethro uses this question to show Moses that what he was doing was not good. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should not be doing all of this for the people!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Why is it that you sit alone ... from morning until evening?
tn.text: Jethro used this question to show Moses that he was doing too much. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should not sit alone ...  from morning till evening!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

The word "sit" here is a metonym for "judge." Judges would sit while they listened to people's complaints. AT: "you judge alone" or "you are the only one who judges the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: You will surely wear yourselves out
tn.text: "you will surely make  yourselves very tired"

tn.ref: This burden is too heavy for you
tn.text: Jethro speaks of the hard work that Moses is doing as if it were a physical burden that Moses was carrying. AT: "This work is too much for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"guidance" or "instruction"
Jethro speaks of God helping Moses as if God would be with Moses. AT: "God will help you" or "God will give you wisdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you bring their disputes to him
tn.text: Jethro speaks of Moses telling God about their disputes as if Moses were bringing their disputes to God. AT: "`you tell God about their disputes" or "you tell God what they are arguing about" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: You must show them the way to walk
tn.text: Jethro speaks of living or behaving like walking. AT: "You must show them how to live" or "You must show them how to behave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jethro continues speaking to Moses.
"In addition, you must choose" or "You must also choose"

tn.ref: You must put them over people
tn.text: Jethro speaks of giving them authority over people as putting them over people. AT: You must give them authority over people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: thousands, hundreds, fifties, and of tens
tn.text: "groups of 1,000, groups of 100, groups of 50, and groups of 10" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"the simple cases"

tn.ref: the difficult cases they will bring to you
tn.text: Jethro speaks of telling Moses about the difficult cases as bringing him the difficult cases. AT: "the difficult cases they will tell you about" or "when there are difficult cases, they will tell you about them so you can judge them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they will carry the burden with you
tn.text: Jethro speaks of the hard work that they would do as if it were a burden that they would carry. AT: "they will do the hard work with you" or "they will help you do the hard work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
What they will endure can be stated clearly. AT: "endure the stress of the work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Moses writes of the leaders of people as if they were the head of a body.  AT: "leaders of the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
What they were capable of doing can be stated clearly. AT: "men who were able to lead" or "men who were able to judge" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"situations"

tn.ref: The difficult cases they brought to Moses
tn.text: The author writes of telling Moses about the difficult cases as bringing him the difficult cases. AT: "the difficult cases they told Moses about" or "when there were difficult cases, they told Moses about them so that he would judge them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the easy cases"
